aGBSAx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Subterranean streams and aquifers in limestone formations of the Douherty Plain.  Very limited range.

references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.B92MEA01SEGP: Means, D. B. 1992. Georgia blind salamander. Rare and Endangered Biota of Florida: Amphibians and Reptiles. P. E. Moler ed.  Gainesville, Florida: University of Florida; 3 pp. 49-53.
references.B88ASH01NAUS: Ashton, R. E., Jr., and P. S. Ashton. 1988. Handbook of reptiles and amphibians of Florida. Part Three. The amphibians. Windward Publ. Co., Miami.

habitat_description: These translucent salamanders are specialized in their habitat requirements and are known to exist only in subterranean streams or pools within limestone caves.  Because of these restrictions, they may be vulnerable any changes within these caves.  Less than 15 localities in Florida [<17 overall] (Means 1992).  Geologic formations containing caves are little known and more localities may exist (Ashton 1988).  Currently known from only a few caves in the Dougherty Plain region of Georgia and Florida.
